The air in Kaelen’s Grafton flat was a tangible thing, a humid soup of stale spell-smoke, damp books, and the ever-present perfume of the city's exhaust fumes creeping through the rattling window frames. He ran a finger over the drooping leaf of a peace lily, whispering a soft, sibilant word. A faint green light, no brighter than a glow-worm's pulse, flowed from his fingertip into the plant's vascular system. The leaf, once a pathetic, limp flag of surrender, slowly began to rise, its colour deepening from a jaundiced yellow to a tentative, hopeful green. It was a small magic, a quiet nudge to the world’s latent vitality, the kind of work that paid no bills but kept his soul from curdling. Most of his life was like this: small nudges, quiet coercions of reality that barely made a ripple. He was a warlock, yes, but not the kind from fables. He didn't command legions or shatter mountains. He mostly found lost keys, encouraged stubborn boilers to work, and occasionally, for a hefty price, untangled the minor curses people picked up like burrs from dabbling in things they didn't understand. Auckland was full of them; a city built on a bed of dormant volcanoes was bound to have thin spots, places where the mundane world wore through and something else peered in.

He was about to give the peace lily a final, encouraging pat when the sound came. It wasn't loud, just a thin, reedy cry carried on the morning air from one of the posher, sprawling properties on the far side of the gully. *Cock-a-doodle-doo*. The words are a lie, he thought, a childish bandage slapped over a sound of pure, primordial malice. It was a shriek, a tearing of the morning’s fabric. Kaelen’s breath hitched. The green light at his fingertip sputtered and died. The peace lily’s leaf drooped again, as if in sympathy. Cold sweat prickled his scalp, a familiar and loathed sensation. His heart began a frantic, clumsy drumbeat against his ribs, a trapped bird fluttering against a cage. The image flashed, unbidden and sharp as broken glass, behind his eyes: a tiny, wattled head, jerking with reptilian speed. Eyes like black, polished beads of hate. A beak, a wicked yellow hook, opening in a saw-toothed crow. He flinched, physically recoiling from the memory, stumbling back until his leg hit the edge of his cluttered desk. Grimoires and unpaid power bills slid to the floor in a messy cascade. He didn't notice. He was breathing through his mouth, short, sharp gasps, staring at the window as if the feathered devil itself was about to crash through it. He hated them. Not with a simple dislike, but with a deep, cellular terror that bypassed reason and clawed right into his hindbrain. It was a stupid, humiliating fear for a man who could, on a good day, persuade the laws of physics to take a brief holiday. But it was his.

The shimmer started in the air beside the dying peace lily. It began as a heat-haze, a distortion of the space, then coalesced into a floating sigil of silver and sapphire light: a stylised 'A' entwined with a phoenix. The Alistair family crest. An old money sigil, dripping with the kind of power that came from generations of never having to look at a price tag. The shimmering light pulsed, and a woman’s voice, clipped and imperious, echoed not in the room, but directly inside Kaelen’s head. *“Mr. Kaelen Blackwood? It is Genevieve Alistair. We require your services. A matter of… domestic security. My wards have failed. There is an unwelcome presence. The address is 14A Arney Crescent, Remuera. The usual consultation fee will be doubled. We expect you within the hour.”* The sigil held for a moment longer, a silent, imperious demand, then dissolved into a shower of harmless silver sparks that vanished before they hit the threadbare carpet.

Remuera. Of course. The part of Auckland where the air itself seemed filtered, where the hedges were more immaculately groomed than most people’s hair. And double the fee meant she was either desperate or terrified. Probably both. A presence her own family wards couldn't handle was serious. Family wards, especially for clans like the Alistairs, were layered things, built up over decades, woven from the very will of the bloodline. For something to bypass them suggested a focused, powerful, and deeply malevolent intent. It was the kind of job that could set him up for six months, a chance to finally fix the leak in the bathroom and replace the books he’d lost to the resulting mould. But it was also the kind of job that got people hurt. He stood, forcing the frantic rhythm of his heart to slow, pushing the image of the beak and the hate-filled eyes into a locked box in the back of his mind. He scooped up a handful of powdered iron from a jar on his desk, rubbing it between his palms. The metallic grit was grounding, a tether to the tangible. The fear receded, leaving behind the slick, bitter residue of adrenaline. He could still feel the echo of that crow in his bones, a low, resonant hum of pure dread.

He put on his best coat, a dark wool number that was only slightly frayed at the cuffs, and grabbed his bag. It was an old leather satchel, stained and scuffed, but its pockets were lined with spells of containment and misdirection. Inside were the tools of his trade: chalk sticks made from crushed seashells and blessed under a full moon, a small silver mirror for scrying, a pouch of salt from the shores of Rangitoto, and a tightly-stoppered vial containing a single, captured sunbeam – a last resort, and hellishly difficult to procure. He locked his flat, the deadbolt sounding unnervingly loud in the quiet hallway, and stepped out into the Auckland morning. The humidity had already clamped down, a wet blanket pressing on the city. The sky was the colour of a day-old bruise, threatening another downpour. He decided against the bus. For a job this big, he needed to arrive with a clear head, not one rattled by the lurch and squeal of public transport. He walked to the corner, focused his will on the ley line that ran beneath Dominion Road, a vibrant, thrumming artery of raw power, and gently, carefully, *pulled*. The world didn't blur or warp. Instead, it folded. The space between his corner and the foot of Arney Crescent simply ceased to exist for a single, seamless moment. One step carried him across three suburbs. He arrived in a quiet, tree-lined street that smelled of money, cut grass, and blooming jasmine. The transition left a faint metallic taste in his mouth, the price of bending geography.

Number 14A was less a house and more a fortress of glass, steel, and stark white concrete, clinging to the side of the hill with an air of architectural arrogance. It looked more like a modern art gallery than a home. He could feel the magic of the place before he even reached the gate. It was a mess. The Alistair wards were in tatters, hanging like shredded spiderwebs in the astral plane. He could see the jagged holes, the frayed ends where they had been torn, not unpicked, but brutally ripped apart. This wasn't subtle. This was a statement. As he approached the towering front door, a new scent reached him, cutting through the pleasant smell of jasmine and rain-washed earth. It was faint, but utterly unmistakable, a foul miasma that made the hairs on his arms stand up. It was the smell of stagnant pond water, of meat left too long in the sun, of rot and deep, abiding filth, all underpinned by a sharp, coppery tang of corrupted magic. His stomach turned. Silas Grime. It couldn't be anyone else. No other warlock in Auckland, perhaps in the whole of New Zealand, carried that signature stench of decay. Grime was a parasite, a magical bottom-feeder who specialized in hexes, extortions, and trafficking in cursed artifacts. He was powerful in a crude, brutish way, like a sledgehammer to Kaelen's scalpel. But what was he doing here? This was far too high-class a target for a grub like Grime. He didn't have the finesse to crack wards like the Alistairs'. He shouldn't have been able to get close. Unless… unless he wasn't trying to be subtle. Unless he was just showing he could. Kaelen paused, his hand hovering over the intercom. The doubled fee suddenly seemed wholly inadequate. This wasn't a simple security job anymore. This was a territorial dispute. And with a warlock who smelled like a blocked sewer, that was never a clean fight. The distant, imagined sound of a rooster's crow echoed in his memory, a shrill, mocking laugh.

He pressed the intercom button. It didn't buzz; it chimed, a series of three soft, melodic notes that sounded expensive. A disembodied voice, smoother and more polished than Genevieve’s telepathic summons, inquired, “Yes?” It was a voice that had never had to raise itself.

“Kaelen Blackwood for Mrs. Alistair.”

There was a pause, a faint click, and the heavy steel gate swung inward with silent, hydraulic grace. He walked up a path of floating stone slabs set over a meticulously raked Zen garden of black sand. The smell of decay grew stronger here, a nauseating counterpoint to the sterile beauty of the landscaping. It was like finding a maggot in a surgeon's sterile tray. The front door, a monolithic slab of dark timber, opened before he reached it. The interior was cavernous and cool, a cathedral of minimalism. The walls were white, the floors were polished concrete, and a vast wall of glass looked out over the green tumble of the gully. The furniture was sparse, sculptural, and looked deeply uncomfortable. Standing in the centre of the vast space was a woman who could only be Genevieve Alistair. She was tall and slim, perhaps in her late sixties, with a severe white bob and a simple but exquisitely cut black dress. Her only adornment was a single, enormous pearl on a silver chain. She held herself with the ramrod posture of someone used to absolute obedience, but Kaelen could see the fine tremor in her hands and the dark, sleepless circles under her eyes.

“Mr. Blackwood. Thank you for your promptness,” she said, her voice as crisp as it had been in his head. She did not offer to shake his hand. “The… problem is in the lower garden.”

Kaelen’s gaze swept the room, not at the art or the view, but at the invisible world superimposed over it. The shredded remains of her wards fluttered like ghostly prayer flags in a gale he could feel but not hear. Grime’s stench was a greasy film coating everything. “Your wards weren’t just bypassed, Mrs. Alistair. They were savaged. This was an act of extreme aggression. Do you know a warlock by the name of Silas Grime?”

Genevieve Alistair’s perfectly composed face tightened. A flicker of something—disgust, perhaps recognition—crossed her features. “The name is… vaguely familiar. A disreputable character, I believe. Are you suggesting he is responsible for this intrusion?”

“His magical signature is all over your property. It’s the equivalent of him spray-painting his name on your front door,” Kaelen said bluntly. He walked towards the wall of glass, looking down into a terraced garden that descended towards the gully. “You said the presence was in the lower garden. What, exactly, *is* it?”

She hesitated, a rare sign of uncertainty. For the first time, a hint of colour touched her pale cheeks. “It’s… a bird.”

Kaelen froze, his back to her. A cold, heavy dread began to congeal in his gut. “A bird?” he asked, his voice carefully neutral.

“A rooster,” she clarified, the word spoken with profound distaste, as if describing a particularly unpleasant form of vermin. “It appeared at dawn. On the sundial. My husband… my late husband, was a collector of exotic poultry. We had a small, warded coop for his prize-winners. But that was years ago. This one… it is not a normal animal. It crows, and the sound… it feels like it’s scraping the inside of my skull. The gardeners refuse to go near it. The dog won’t leave the house. My own cantrips slide right off it. It just stands there. Watching.”

The room seemed to tilt. The imagined sound from his flat was now a real and present threat, waiting for him just a few hundred feet away. His phobia, the humiliating, childish secret, was the very monster he was being paid double to fight. Of course. The universe had a sick sense of humour, and Silas Grime, it seemed, shared it. This wasn't just a show of force. This was a message, tailored and deeply personal, though Grime couldn't possibly know its full effect. Or could he? The thought sent a fresh wave of ice through his veins. He forced himself to turn, to face her, hoping the mask of the calm professional was holding.

“A rooster,” he repeated, the words tasting like ash. “Sent by Grime. To do what? Annoy you to death?”

“Don’t be flippant, Mr. Blackwood,” she snapped, her composure cracking. “My family has held this land for five generations. Our wards are tied to our blood. For an outside entity to not only breach them but to place a totem of its power within them is a profound violation. It is an act of war. This creature is an anchor. A foothold. From it, he can poison the ley lines of my property, corrupt my defences from the inside, and hold my home hostage. I want it gone. Now.”

Kaelen took a slow, deliberate breath, fighting down the frantic bird in his own chest. He could feel the rooster’s presence now that he knew what to look for, a small, tight knot of malevolent energy at the bottom of the garden, pulsing with a dull, filthy rhythm. It was Grime's magic, condensed and given legs, feathers, and a beak. And it was waiting. He swallowed hard, the metallic tang of the fold-step returning to his tongue. “I’ll need to see it,” he said, his voice sounding distant to his own ears. “To assess the nature of the enchantment before I attempt a banishment.”

Genevieve nodded sharply, gesturing towards a glass door that led out onto a balcony with a spiral staircase. “Be my guest. Your fee will be transferred the moment the creature is no longer on my property.” She paused, her gaze sharp and assessing. “You look pale, Mr. Blackwood. Are you quite well?”

“Perfectly,” Kaelen lied, the word feeling clumsy and foreign in his mouth. “Just concentrating.” He pushed open the door and stepped out into the humid air, the scent of jasmine, wet earth, and Grime’s rot swirling around him. Below, at the very edge of the manicured lawn where it met the wilder bush of the gully, was a stone sundial. And on it, a silhouette that made his blood run cold. It was preternaturally still, a dark shape against the grey sky, its head held high. And as if it knew it was being watched, it stretched its neck, threw back its head, and let out another soul-tearing shriek. The sound wasn't just a noise; it was a weapon, and it hit Kaelen with the force of a physical blow, making his teeth ache and his vision swim. The world contracted to a single point of terror: the feathered demon on the sundial.

He gripped the cold metal railing of the balcony, his knuckles white. The world swam back into focus, but the echo of the crow remained, a high-frequency whine at the edge of his hearing, a shard of sound lodged in his brain. His every instinct screamed at him to turn, to walk back inside, to tell Genevieve Alistair that her money wasn't worth it. He could be back in his flat in a single fold-step, the rattling window and the dying peace lily a familiar, safe misery. But the image of the mould-damaged books and the red-lettered power bills rose alongside the terror. He needed this. More than that, letting a thug like Grime chase him off a job with a magically-enhanced chicken was a professional humiliation he couldn't afford. Reputation was a currency as real as coin in his line of work, and his was already precarious.

Taking a shuddering breath that did little to calm him, Kaelen forced his warlock's senses to the forefront, pushing past the blaring sirens of his phobia. He narrowed his eyes, looking not at the physical form of the rooster, but at the magical energies it radiated. It was worse than he'd thought. The creature was a vortex, a focal point of putrid, stagnant power. Grime's filthy magic wasn't just *in* the rooster; it *was* the rooster. It was a construct, animated by a sliver of some minor malevolent spirit Grime had bound and wrapped in a shell of conjured flesh and feathers. He could see the tendrils of its influence already sinking into the earth around the sundial, thin, black, greasy roots worming their way towards the ley line that fed the property, seeking to poison it at its source. Genevieve was right. It was an anchor, and if left unchecked, Grime could use it to unravel the very fabric of the place.

He decided to try a probe, a gentle test of its defences. Keeping one hand firmly on the railing as a physical anchor, he lifted the other and whispered a simple cantrip of unbinding, a spell usually sufficient to unravel minor enchantments. He aimed it not at the creature itself, but at the space just above it, hoping to tease at the edges of its aura. A thin thread of silver light, barely visible in the grey morning, shot from his fingers. The moment it touched the rooster's sphere of influence, it didn't just fizzle out; it was violently snuffed out, consumed by the cloying darkness. The rooster on the sundial, which had been perfectly still, twitched its head. It lifted one scaly, yellow foot and deliberately scratched a long, sharp line into the sundial's bronze face. The shriek of metal on metal was almost as bad as its crow. As it drew its claw back, the scratch glowed with a faint, sickly purple light before fading. A sigil of corruption. It knew he was there. It knew what he was. And it was mocking him.

"Right," Kaelen muttered to himself, the single word a surrender. There was no avoiding it. He couldn't deal with this from a safe distance. He had to go down there, into its sphere of influence, and cut it out like the tumour it was. He turned and gave a stiff nod to Mrs. Alistair, who was watching him from the doorway with an unreadable expression. "I'm going down. I would advise you to stay inside. Don't watch." She gave a curt, dismissive wave, as if the idea of watching had never occurred to her, and retreated into the cool shadows of her minimalist palace. Kaelen was alone with his fear. He took the spiral staircase, each step a conscious act of will. The metal was cold and slick with morning dew. With every turn, the scent of Grime's magic intensified, overpowering the jasmine and cut grass. It was a smell of true decay, not the honest rot of a forest floor, but the sour, unhealthy decomposition of a cursed thing. His stomach churned, and the adrenaline from his earlier panic returned, but this time it was colder, sharper. It was the feeling of walking into a fight he wasn't sure he could win.

He reached the bottom of the staircase and stepped onto the immaculate lawn. The grass was like a deep-pile carpet under his worn boots. The air here was thick and heavy, charged with a hostile energy that made his skin prickle. The lower garden was an exercise in controlled nature, with sculpted hedges and carefully placed flowerbeds of muted colours. But near the sundial, the perfection was beginning to fray. The edges of the lawn closest to it were turning a sickly brown, and a bed of white roses was visibly wilting, their petals curling and blackening at the tips as if touched by a sudden, blighting frost. The rooster stood in the centre of this small circle of decay, a monument of feathered malice. It hadn't moved, but he could feel its attention on him, a palpable, hateful pressure. Up close, it was even more unnatural. Its feathers were the colour of dried blood, its comb and wattles a livid, bruised purple. But its eyes were the worst part. They weren't the simple, reactive eyes of a bird. They were ancient and intelligent, black pits of cold malevolence that seemed to look straight through him, seeing the frantic, scared child hiding behind the warlock's weary facade.

### Chapter 2

He forced his legs to move, each step a small victory against the tide of panic that threatened to sweep him away. His hands were shaking, not with the fine tremor of a warlock manipulating delicate energies, but with the coarse, animal fear of a cornered prey. He needed an anchor, a piece of solid, dependable magic to stand on. He unslung his satchel, his numb fingers fumbling with the clasp. The familiar scent of its contents—the dry dust of chalk, the sharp brine of salt, the faint, clean aroma of the captured sunbeam—was a small comfort in the hostile air. He ignored the more potent tools, his hand closing around a stick of chalk, cool and solid in his sweaty palm. A containment circle. It was foundational magic, the kind apprentices learned in their first year, but its strength lay in its simplicity. It was a line drawn in the world, a statement of intent: *this space is mine, and you are not welcome in it*.

He took a deep breath and stepped forward, bending to draw the first arc on the manicured lawn. The moment the chalk touched the grass, the rooster moved. It wasn't a sudden attack. It was a slow, deliberate tilt of its head, a gesture of mocking curiosity that was chillingly intelligent. Its black bead eyes followed the white line as he painstakingly drew it, the silence stretching taut. Then, as he completed the first half of the circle, it threw its head back and crowed again. This time the sound was not a general broadcast of malice but a focused, psychic lance aimed directly at him. It struck his mind with a concussive force, filling his head with images of falling from great heights, of being buried alive, of rot and suffocation. His vision went white at the edges and the chalk stick slipped, scarring a broken line in the grass. The terror was a physical thing now, a suffocating weight on his chest. He gasped, falling to one knee, the litany of his phobia screaming in his skull: *the beak, the eyes, the hate, the hate…*

From some deep, stubborn well of professional pride, he found a sliver of defiance. He was Kaelen Blackwood. He untangled curses. He coaxed reality. He would not be broken by a phantom chicken conjured by a magical slob. He grit his teeth, the taste of iron filling his mouth, and forced his hand to close around the chalk again. He ignored the screaming in his head, focusing every scrap of his will on the simple, physical act of drawing a white line on green grass. He made the circle a full ten feet in diameter, a generous space, and as he drew the final, connecting arc, he whispered a single, sharp word of sealing. The air inside the circle instantly changed. The oppressive, hateful pressure lessened, as if a heavy blanket had been partially lifted. The psychic shriek of the rooster’s presence was now muffled, its sharp edges blunted by the simple boundary. He was still terrified, but it was his terror now, contained within him, not an invasive force being hammered into his skull.

Safe for the moment, he reached back into his satchel and drew out the small, silver scrying mirror. His reflection was a pale, sweat-slicked stranger. He carefully angled the mirror so it did not show the rooster’s physical form, but instead captured the space where it stood. He narrowed his eyes, pushing his senses through the silvered glass, peeling back the layer of the mundane to see the magical truth beneath. What he saw was as crude and disgusting as Grime’s reputation. The rooster was a prison. At its heart was a miserable, writhing knot of spirit-stuff, a minor malevolent entity that Grime had likely summoned from some stagnant metaphysical backwater. It was held in its feathered shape by thick, ugly chains of magic, pulsing with a purple-black light. And from the base of the construct, a single, thick taproot of congealed power plunged deep into the earth, a black, oily hook seeking to foul the bright, clean energy of the ley line that ran beneath the property. It was a masterpiece of brutish, effective malevolence.

The creature on the sundial seemed to sense his scrutiny. The purple sigil its claw had scratched into the bronze flared with a sudden, violent light. A wave of palpable corruption, visible to Kaelen's heightened senses as a tide of greasy, black sludge, rolled outward from the sundial. It didn't just carry a feeling of despair; it carried the stench of it, a psychic miasma of utter hopelessness. The wave struck his chalk circle and the white line hissed and sputtered like water on a hot pan, turning a dark, soiled brown. The circle held, but the boundary groaned under the assault, and Kaelen felt the psychic pressure increase tenfold. He stumbled back, the mirror nearly falling from his grasp. The construct wasn't just a passive anchor; it was an active weapon, and it knew he was trying to dismantle it. He had to sever its connection to the land, and he had to do it now.

There was no time for a delicate unravelling. This called for amputation. He looked at the wilting roses, their life force being leeched away by Grime's parasitic spell. He looked at the vibrant green grass inside his circle, then at the sickening brown that was creeping towards it. The answer was there. The problem and the solution lay in the same place: the earth beneath his feet. Grime was using the land as a source of poison. Kaelen would use it as a source of power. Drawing directly from a ley line without preparation was incredibly dangerous, like trying to catch a lightning bolt in a bottle, but he had no other choice. The slow, careful nudges he was used to wouldn't work. He needed a flood.

He dropped to one knee, ignoring the screaming protest of his nerves, and pressed his right palm flat against the living grass inside his circle. He closed his eyes, shutting out the sight of the feathered horror, and reached down with his will. He bypassed the topsoil, the roots, the clay, and sought the vibrant, thrumming river of energy he had ridden across the city. He felt it, a current of immense, clean power flowing deep below. He didn't try to command it or pull from it. Instead, he presented the problem—the festering wound of Grime’s magic—and humbly asked for the strength to cleanse it. For a terrifying second, there was nothing. Then, the ley line responded. A torrent of pure, undiluted vitality, smelling of deep earth and thunderstorms, surged up, not into his body, but *through* it. The world behind his eyelids exploded in green-gold light. His hair stood on end, and a tremor ran through him, not of fear, but of raw, untamed power.

Opening his eyes, which now glowed with a faint, verdant luminescence, Kaelen rose to his feet. He had become a conduit, a temporary channel for the life force of the land itself. He raised his left hand, no longer trembling, and aimed it at the creature on the sundial. He didn't cast a spell or speak a word; he simply opened the gate. A wave of incandescent green-gold energy, a tidal wave of pure life, erupted from him. It wasn't a destructive force, but a creative one, an unmaking by way of overwhelming vitality. The wave of life washed over the circle of decay, and where it passed, the brown grass instantly greened, the wilting roses straightened, their petals uncurling.

When the wave of pure life hit the construct, the effect was instantaneous and grotesque. The rooster’s final crow was cut short, twisting into a polyphonic shriek of a dozen tortured voices as the spirit within was annihilated by the purifying force. Its shape destabilised violently. The blood-red feathers turned to clouds of fine grey ash and were whipped away on a sudden breeze. The bruised purple flesh and scaly legs lost all cohesion, melting into a pool of thick, bubbling black sludge that dripped from the sundial. The oily taproot of magic connecting it to the earth was seared away, not with fire, but with an intensity of life it could not endure. In a matter of seconds, it was over.

A profound, ringing silence descended on the lower garden. The oppressive weight was gone, the air scrubbed clean. The only remaining scent was the clean smell of ozone and damp earth. On the sundial, where the monster had stood, there was now only a smear of foul-smelling, inert black grease and the ugly scratch of its sigil. The ley line’s power receded, leaving Kaelen feeling scoured, hollowed out, and shaking with a weakness that went bone-deep. He swayed on his feet, the world greying at the edges as the adrenaline and borrowed power abandoned him in a dizzying rush. He stumbled forward, his own circle now just a brown smudge on the lawn, and braced himself against the sundial. It was just a sundial now, cool stone and bronze. As he caught his breath, a faint, almost imperceptible *ping* sounded in the quietest corner of his mind. A telepathic notification. The doubled fee, transferred to his account. Cold. Immediate. Impersonal. He stared at the black sludge, the residue of his deepest fear, and felt nothing close to victory. He had faced the demon, and he had won. But the fight had left him empty, and the echo of its hateful, black eyes was now a permanent resident in the back of his mind.

He pushed himself upright, his muscles screaming in protest. The raw power had used him as a wire, and now he felt like a burnt-out fuse. Every joint ached, and a low-grade tremor had taken up residence in his hands, a souvenir from the ley line’s torrential energy. He ran a weary hand over his face, the grit of the iron powder he’d used earlier mixing with a film of cold sweat. The job was done. The immediate, screeching terror was gone. But the silence it left behind was almost worse, filled with the phantom echo of its cry and the lingering, visceral memory of its unnatural presence. This was the part of the job they never mentioned in the fables: the debilitating magical hangover and the quiet, personal cost of tearing a hole in reality, even to let the light in.

The glass door to the house slid open with a whisper of expensive technology. Genevieve Alistair stepped out onto the balcony, her severe black dress a stark slash against the now-brightening garden. She didn't descend the stairs but stood on the balcony, surveying her reclaimed territory with the air of a queen inspecting a freshly won battlefield. Her gaze swept over the rejuvenated lawn, the recovering roses, and finally settled on the black, viscous stain marring the face of her sundial. Her expression didn't change; there was no relief, no gratitude, only a cold, critical assessment of the remaining damage.

“The noise has stopped,” she observed, her voice carrying clearly in the clean air. “I assume the creature is dealt with.”

“It was a construct, not a creature. And yes, it’s dealt with,” Kaelen said, his voice raspy. He was too exhausted for professional niceties. He gestured with a shaking hand towards the sundial. “But this isn’t over. That’s the wound it left.” He pointed to the ugly scratch glowing with a faint, residual malevolence. “And that,” he added, nudging the pool of black sludge with the toe of his boot, “is his signature. Silas Grime isn’t just knocking on your door, Mrs. Alistair. He’s kicked it down, taken a dump on your prize rug, and left you a bill for the privilege. He’ll be back. This was a test of your defences, and a declaration.”

Genevieve descended the spiral staircase, her movements fluid and unhurried. She stopped a careful ten feet from the sundial, her upper lip curling slightly at the smell that still hung over the sludge. She was not a woman who countenanced filth, magical or otherwise. The information didn’t seem to frighten her; it angered her. Kaelen could see it in the tightening of her jaw, the way her eyes, cold as a winter sea, hardened into chips of ice. The personal violation was a far greater crime to her than the potential danger.

“Grime,” she said, tasting the name as if it were poison. “I have had my people look into him since our communication. A bottom-feeder. A parasite who preys on the foolish and the weak. For him to dare this… it is an intolerable presumption.” She turned her sharp gaze on Kaelen, her eyes boring into him. “You were effective, Mr. Blackwood. More so than I was led to believe. Your methods are… forceful, but the result is satisfactory. The anchor is gone. Now, we address the root cause. What do you propose?”

Kaelen took a steadying breath, trying to marshal his thoughts through the fog of exhaustion. “There are two paths,” he said, laying it out plainly. “The defensive path is to cleanse this land of his taint, which will take a few days, and then I help your own people rebuild your wards. We’ll layer them with counters to his specific magical signature. It’ll be expensive and time-consuming, and it turns your home into a fortress. It’s the sensible option.” He paused, letting that sink in before continuing. “The other path is proactive. You hire me to go after him. To deliver a message of your own. To make him understand that the Alistair family is not a target, but a predator. That is not a clean fight. It’s not sensible. And it’s certainly not cheap.”

A long, heavy silence fell between them, broken only by the distant hum of Auckland traffic. Genevieve Alistair stared at the sundial, at the ugly scar left on her property, her heritage. The slight tremor in her hand from earlier was gone, replaced by a stillness that was far more menacing. She had come to a decision long before he’d finished speaking.

“Mr. Blackwood,” she said, her voice dropping to a low, chillingly calm register. “I am not in the business of building fortresses. My family did not achieve its position by hiding behind walls. We achieved it by removing obstacles.” She met his gaze, and for the first time, he felt the full, crushing weight of the power she wielded, a power that had nothing to do with magic and everything to do with generations of unassailable wealth and influence. “I am not paying you to be sensible. I am paying you for your… forceful methods. I want Silas Grime removed. Not his magic, not his influence. Him. I want him to be made an example of, a cautionary tale whispered by people of his ilk for the next fifty years. Name your price.”

The offer hung in the air, vast and terrifying. The kind of money she was implying wouldn’t just fix his bathroom leak; it would buy him a new flat, a new life, a future free from the gnawing anxiety of overdue bills. It was freedom, dangling right in front of him. But the price was a war with a warlock who used soul-shredding constructs as calling cards. A warlock who, for some reason, had chosen a totem that was the key to Kaelen’s most private, humiliating terror. The thought sent a jolt of cold dread through him, more chilling than the ley line’s power. How could Grime have known? Was it a coincidence? Or was the attack even more personal than he’d imagined?

A memory fragment, sharp and unwelcome as a shard of glass, flashed behind his eyes. Not the rooster construct, but something older. The smell of sun-baked hay and dust motes dancing in a barn’s dim light. The sound of a child’s laughter turning into a high, thin scream. A flash of wicked yellow beak, impossibly close to his face. He flinched, the phantom pain making his eyes water. He was six years old again, trapped and terrified, and the thing that had savaged him then wore the same shape as the thing he had just destroyed.

He looked at Genevieve Alistair, at her perfect posture and her bottomless bank account, and then at the smear of black filth that was all that remained of his personal demon. This wasn't just about a job anymore. It wasn't just about money, or even professional pride. Silas Grime had reached into Kaelen's past and dredged up a monster. Whether he knew it or not, he had made this a blood feud. Kaelen’s exhaustion was momentarily forgotten, burned away by a sudden, cold flare of rage.

“The price,” Kaelen said, his voice steady now, all trace of weakness gone, “is that you stay out of my way. You provide me with any and all information you have on him. And you cover all expenses, no questions asked. My fee will be determined upon completion.” He met her icy gaze without flinching. “I’ll take the job.”

### Chapter 3

A flicker of a smile, thin and sharp as a razor’s edge, touched Genevieve Alistair’s lips before vanishing. “Good,” she said. The single word was a confirmation, a seal on their dark contract. She turned without another glance at the mess on the sundial and swept back towards the house, expecting him to follow. Kaelen remained for a moment, the cold rage in his chest giving way to the profound, aching weariness of his body. A job was a job. He had professional standards. He knelt, unslung his satchel, and retrieved the pouch of salt from Rangitoto’s shores. Uncorking it, he poured a small, coarse white mound onto the black sludge. The salt hissed as if touching acid, and a puff of foul, grey smoke rose from the goo, smelling of burnt hair and stagnant water. He whispered a quiet word of cleansing, a simple but potent banality that scoured the last of Grime’s foulness from the bronze. The ugly scratch remained, a physical scar, but the malignant energy within it guttered and died. When he was done, the sundial was just an object again, violated but inert.

He followed her inside, back into the cavernous, air-conditioned cool of the house. The transition was jarring, from the raw, organic mess of the garden to this sterile temple of wealth. The faint tremor had returned to his hands, and he shoved them into the pockets of his coat to conceal it. He felt hollowed out, as if the ley line had not only flowed through him but had also taken a part of him with it when it receded. Genevieve stood by a floating countertop of polished obsidian, a bottle of what looked like impossibly expensive whisky in one hand and a heavy crystal tumbler in the other.

“A drink, Mr. Blackwood? To seal our arrangement.”

“Water would be fine,” he said, his throat feeling like sandpaper. “And a tablet for the headache you’re about to give me.” She raised a perfectly sculpted eyebrow at his bluntness but turned to a nearly invisible panel in the wall. A moment later, a glass of chilled water and two white pills sat on the counter beside the whisky. He downed the pills with a grateful swallow of water. It tasted of nothing, which in itself felt luxurious.

“My consultant has already compiled a preliminary file,” she said, sliding a wafer-thin tablet across the obsidian surface. “We have been aware of the city’s… substrata for some time. It pays to be informed.” Kaelen picked it up. The file was sparse but dense with the kind of information that was hard to come by legally. Known associates, a network of petty magical criminals and fences. A string of last-known addresses, mostly condemned buildings and transient squats in the city's grimier suburbs. There was even a grainy surveillance photo of a large, shambling man with a greasy ponytail leaving a notorious back-alley pub in Otahuhu. The man looked like he showered in a deep-fryer. It had to be Grime.

“This is a good start,” Kaelen admitted, impressed despite himself. “But it’s all reactive. It’s where he’s been. I need to know where he is now, or where he’s going. This attack was bold, Mrs. Alistair. Far bolder than the profile of a simple parasite suggests. He’s either become more powerful, or more desperate. Why you? Why now? Has your family acquired anything recently? An artifact, a property with a history? Something he might feel he has a claim to?”

Her expression was one of immense distaste, as if he’d asked to see her bank statements. “My family’s acquisitions are extensive, Mr. Blackwood. To suggest any of them would have a connection to this… person…”

“He used a construct that keyed directly into a deep-seated, personal phobia of mine,” Kaelen cut in, his voice dangerously quiet. “That is either the most astronomically unlikely coincidence in the history of magic, or he did it on purpose. If he did it on purpose, it means he knows me. Or knows *of* me. And if he was hired, it means his employer knows me. This is not random. So, I will ask again. What have you bought recently that a man who smells of rot and deals in filth might take an interest in?”

The directness of the question, and the raw, personal detail he’d revealed, seemed to penetrate her armour of detached superiority. She was silent for a long moment, her gaze distant. “There was a foreclosure,” she said eventually, her voice clipped. “A business matter. A small, cluttered property in the Waitākere Ranges. The previous owner had defaulted on several loans. He was a collector of… esoteric antiquities. Junk, mostly. The land was the asset, not the house. It was cleared last week.”

Kaelen froze, the tablet suddenly feeling heavy in his hands. The Waitākere Ranges. A place of deep, old magic, where the bush was thick and the ley lines ran wild and tangled, far from the relatively ordered grid beneath the city. “A collector of esoteric junk,” he repeated slowly. “And one of Grime’s known associates in this file,” he tapped the screen, “is a man named Finnian ‘Fingers’ Coe. A fence for cursed artifacts and black-market components. His primary territory is listed as the western suburbs, out towards the Ranges.” The pieces were slotting together, forming a picture he did not like.

“This collector,” Kaelen pressed, “What was his name?”

Genevieve waved a dismissive hand. “It’s irrelevant. He’s gone.”

“It is the most relevant detail in this entire case,” Kaelen insisted, his patience fraying. “Grime didn’t attack you for your money, Mrs. Alistair. He attacked you for something you took. Something that was in that house.”

She gave him a look of pure steel. “Find it. And find him. That is what I am paying you for.” The conversation was over. She had given him the thread; she expected him to unravel it without bothering her with the details. Kaelen nodded slowly, a cold knot forming in his stomach. He was walking into a turf war over a dead man’s forgotten treasures. It was a classic, grubby recipe for disaster.

He pushed himself away from the counter, his body protesting every movement. “Before I go, you need to take precautions. Your wards are in shreds. Grime left a gaping hole and he knows it.” He looked around the vast, empty room. “Get your staff to lay lines of salt across every threshold and windowsill. The common rock salt you’d use on winter ice, nothing fancy. It won't stop him if he really wants in, but it’ll make him have to force the door, magically speaking. It’ll give you a moment's warning.”

A flicker of annoyance crossed her face at being given instructions in her own home, but she gave a curt nod. “It will be done.” He turned and walked towards the monolithic front door, feeling her cold, assessing gaze on his back the entire way. The door swung open and he stepped out into the humid afternoon. The fold-step back to his flat was out of the question; he felt so drained he worried he’d miscalculate and end up embedded in a wall. Pulling his phone from his pocket, he called a cab. The initial payment from Genevieve was more than enough to cover it. As he waited by the silent, imposing gate, he looked back at the fortress of glass and steel. He had made a deal with one monster to hunt another, and he was standing right in the middle, feeling dangerously like bait. The cab arrived, a blessedly mundane car in a street of silent German sedans. He gave the driver the address of a pub near the foothills of the Waitākeres, a known haunt of Fingers Coe. As the car pulled away from the manicured perfection of Remuera, the adrenaline and rage finally receded, leaving only the deep, resonant ache of exhaustion and the cold, hard certainty of the hunt ahead.

The cab smelled of pine-tree air freshener and old cigarette smoke, a chemical cocktail that did little to mask the scent of damp upholstery. Kaelen leaned his head against the cool glass of the window, watching the manicured perfection of Remuera bleed into the chaotic, vibrant sprawl of suburban Auckland. The journey was a descent, not just in altitude and property values, but in order, from the sterile quiet of the Alistair estate to the noisy, messy reality of the city he called home. He felt the transition in his bones, a loosening of a tension he hadn't realised he was holding. In Genevieve’s world, he was a tool, a necessary but distasteful appliance to be used and put away. Out here, in the land of peeling paint and overflowing bins, he was just a man trying to get by, a status that was both a curse and a strange comfort. The central, terrifying question of the rooster construct gnawed at him, a splinter under the thumbnail of his consciousness. It wasn’t just a rooster; it was a perfect effigy of his childhood trauma. Coincidence was a luxury he couldn't afford to believe in. Silas Grime knew. He had to have known. But how? The list of people who knew about that humiliating, sun-drenched afternoon in a dusty barn was vanishingly small. The knowledge turned the job from a professional obligation into something sharp and deeply personal.

The pub was called The Smuggler’s Rest, a name that was a little too on-the-nose for its clientele. It was a tired-looking building of brick and peeling plaster wedged between a discount tyre shop and a laundromat. A neon sign in the window, meant to depict a cheerful-looking parrot, had a busted transformer that made the bird’s eye flicker in a constant, unnerving wink. Kaelen paid the driver, the small stack of cash feeling flimsy after the telepathic ping of Genevieve’s payment, and pushed through the heavy wooden door. The air inside was a thick, breathing entity, composed of stale beer, fried food, and the low-level hum of desperation. The conversations, a low murmur of grumbles and boasts, faltered for a half-second as he entered, a dozen pairs of eyes giving him a swift, reflexive assessment before dismissing him and turning back to their drinks. He was a stranger, but he was gaunt and weary enough to not register as a threat or a mark. He was just another piece of the city's flotsam, washed up for the evening.

He slid onto a worn stool at the sticky bar, the cheap varnish flaking under his elbows. He didn't scan the room with his eyes. Instead, he closed them for a moment, letting his warlock's senses drift through the space like smoke. He filtered past the faint, pathetic flickers of luck charms tucked into pockets and the sour residue of a hundred minor hangover curses. He was looking for something specific, a particular flavour of magical grime. It was the aura of a man who regularly handled objects saturated with decades of greed, fear, and bad intentions; the spiritual equivalent of engine oil and rust permanently ingrained under the fingernails. He found it clinging to a figure hunched over a pint in the darkest corner of the room, a man trying very hard to be part of the shadows.

The man was wiry and small, with a nervous, twitching energy that even his attempt at stillness couldn't conceal. A lank, greasy curtain of hair fell across his face as he stared intently into his beer. But it was his hands that gave him away. They rested on the table on either side of his glass, and his fingers, long and thin, were stained a dozen different colours—the faint yellow of alchemical sulphur, the deep brown of dried bloodroot, and an ugly, purplish tint that spoke of prolonged contact with poorly contained necromantic energy. Finnian ‘Fingers’ Coe. The man looked up as if sensing the attention, his eyes darting around the room like cornered rodents before quickly dropping back to his drink. The aura of tainted magic around him was a beacon in the dull room, a signpost pointing to a career of trafficking in other people’s misery.

Kaelen ordered a beer he had no intention of drinking, the glass cool and sweating in his hand. He didn’t approach the corner table directly. Instead, he took his drink and moved to an empty two-person table that was uncomfortably close to Coe’s, a deliberate but deniable invasion of his personal space. He sat down, placing his beer on the table with a soft click, and waited. He didn’t look at Coe. He stared at the condensation trailing down his own glass, gathering his focus. With a sliver of will, a quiet nudge no more powerful than his spell on the peace lily, he reached out. The small puddle of spilled beer on Coe’s table, just by his elbow, began to move. It crept, against gravity, into a single, perfect, glistening bead, which then elongated, stretching itself into the unmistakable shape of a human finger, pointing directly at the fence’s own stained hand. He held it for a second, then let it collapse back into a meaningless puddle. It was a parlour trick, but one designed to speak a very specific language.

Fingers Coe went rigid. He’d seen it. Kaelen hadn't doubted he would; a man in his trade would have to have a feel for the subtle motions of the world. Coe’s head snapped up, his frightened eyes finally locking on Kaelen. Kaelen met his gaze and gave him a slow, weary nod. He spoke, his voice barely rising above the pub's low drone. “Finnian Coe. That Idol of a Thousand Eyes you fenced last week? The one you swore was cleansed? It wasn't. The new owner’s dog has started speaking to him. In Akkadian. It’s been telling him to burn things.” He took a slow sip of his beer. “He’s not happy. And when he's not happy, I get phone calls.”

Coe’s sallow face went a shade paler, which Kaelen hadn’t thought possible. “I don’t know what you’re talking about,” he stammered, his eyes flicking towards the door. “I’m just having a drink.” He made to stand up, but Kaelen didn't move a muscle, merely held his gaze. “Sit down, Fingers. This isn't about the idol. This is about your old supplier. Silas Grime.” The name hung in the air between them, thick and foul as Grime’s own stench. Coe flinched as if struck and sank back into his chair, his brief surge of courage utterly deserting him. Fear of Grime was a powerful motivator, but Kaelen’s quiet, specific knowledge of his own illicit dealings was a more immediate and terrifying threat.

“Grime is drawing the wrong kind of attention,” Kaelen continued, leaning forward slightly, his voice dropping into a conspiratorial murmur. “He hit an Alistair property this morning. The old money. He’s in over his head, and he’s dragging his associates down with him. I’m here to cut a line before the whole rig collapses. And you, my friend, are tangled in it.” He let the threat hang, unspoken. Coe was a minnow, and two sharks were circling. His only hope was to give the closer shark what it wanted. Coe swallowed hard, his Adam's apple bobbing. He was trapped, and he knew it. He licked his dry lips, the rodent-like eyes darting around one last time before accepting his fate.

“It was Vance’s place,” he whispered, his voice hoarse. “Elias Vance. Out in the Waitākeres. He was a collector, more of a hoarder. Obsessed. Grime was his main source for years. Supplied him with all the real nasty stuff—spirit-traps, soul-jars, books bound in things you don’t wanna know about. Vance was trying to… to build something. A guardian. A perfect, bound familiar that would be loyal only to him. Grime thought of Vance’s collection as his own personal piggy bank, his retirement plan. When he heard the Alistairs had foreclosed, that they’d just cleaned the place out like it was a rubbish dump… he went berserk. Said they’d stolen his inheritance.”

The final piece of the puzzle clicked into place. This wasn’t a random attack. It was a targeted, vengeful retrieval mission. Grime was after something specific from that house, something he felt was his, and he was willing to start a war with one of the most powerful families in the country to get it back. “He thinks they have it,” Kaelen stated, the exhaustion in his bones momentarily forgotten, replaced by the cold clarity of the chase. “What was it? What was Vance building?” Coe shook his head frantically, genuine ignorance and fear warring in his eyes. “I don’t know. Vance was paranoid. He never said. But it was his life’s work. His ‘magnum opus’, he called it. Whatever it is, Grime wants it back. Badly.” He scribbled an address on a damp napkin and pushed it across the table. “That’s Vance’s place. But you don’t want to go there. The house… it’s not right. Vance didn’t just collect junk, mate. He layered the whole property with it. It’s a magical dump site. A maze of broken wards and half-dead curses. Going in there is suicide.”

Kaelen took the napkin, the address a dark smudge of ink on the flimsy paper. He had what he needed. He stood up, leaving his full beer on the table. He looked down at the terrified little fence, a man drowning in the dangerous currents of a world he only half-understood. “A word of advice, Finnian,” Kaelen said, his voice flat and cold. “The next time Silas Grime contacts you, don’t answer. The man you see as a monster is about to find out what a real monster looks like. And the ground between them is no place for a minnow to be.” He dropped a few coins on the bar to cover his drink and walked out, not looking back. The door swung shut behind him, cutting off the noise and the smell of the pub, leaving him in the relative peace of the drizzly Auckland evening. He stood on the pavement, the damp air cool on his face, and looked west. The Waitākere Ranges were a hulking silhouette against the bruised purple of the twilight sky, a jagged line of deep shadow and ancient secrets. The address on the napkin in his pocket felt like a lodestone, pulling him towards the darkness, towards a dead man’s fortress of magical junk, and towards a final, inevitable confrontation with Silas Grime. The fear was still there, a cold, hard knot in his stomach, but now it was mixed with something else: a grim, burning resolve. This ended now.

### Chapter 4

He didn’t take a cab. The address on the napkin wasn’t a place you could ask to be taken to. It was a place you arrived at, preferably unnoticed. The thought of another fold-step made his bones ache in sympathy, so he settled for a compromise, a low-level manipulation that was more of a polite request than a command. He caught the last bus heading west, settling into a grimy seat at the back, and gently nudged the world around it. The traffic lights on the long, straight artery of the Great North Road seemed to sense his approach, turning a welcoming green. Other cars found reasons to turn off, leaving their lane clear. It was a small, draining magic, but it shaved twenty minutes off the journey, carrying him out of the city’s dense, ordered grid of power and into the wild, tangled energies of the Waitākere Ranges. He felt the shift as a change in pressure, the air growing thick and heavy with the raw, untamed magic of the ancient forest. It was a primal power, smelling of deep, wet earth, of decay and ferocious growth, and it made the hair on his arms stand up.

The bus sighed to a halt at its final stop, a lonely shelter at the edge of the encroaching bush. The driver gave him a strange look as he disembarked, the only passenger to ride it all the way to the end of the line. From there, he walked. The road narrowed, the asphalt cracking and giving way to gravel, the streetlights vanishing completely. The sounds of the city were replaced by the rhythmic thrum of crickets and the whisper of wind through the dense canopy of native trees. The air was cool and damp, and the darkness beneath the trees was absolute. He followed the address on the napkin, his warlock’s senses a more reliable guide than the dim light of his phone. He felt the property before he saw it, a sour note in the rich, dark symphony of the forest’s natural magic. It was a pocket of dissonance, a place where the natural flow of energy sickened and curdled.

The house itself was barely visible from the road, a dark, hunched shape almost completely consumed by overgrown bush and climbing vines. A rusted iron gate, half off its hinges, barred a driveway that was now little more than a muddy track. As he stood before it, Kaelen finally understood the true meaning of Fingers Coe’s warning. It wasn’t just a messy house; it was a magical landfill. He closed his eyes and let his senses sift through the oppressive atmosphere. It was a cacophony. Dozens, perhaps hundreds of enchantments, wards, and minor curses were layered over one another, a tangled, decaying web of conflicting intents. He could feel the pathetic bleat of a flawed burglar alarm that would alert a demon in a forgotten dimension, the sticky pull of a containment spell that had long ago broken and was now just a patch of magically adhesive air, and the faint, spiteful buzz of a dozen half-hearted hexes laid on the fence posts. It was the legacy of a man who had collected magic like stamps, appreciating the pattern but never understanding the power.

As his senses adjusted to the overwhelming noise, a familiar, nauseating signal cut through the chaos like a scream in a library. It was the scent of Silas Grime’s power, a greasy, foul signature that felt like a physical slick on the astral plane. He had been here, and recently. His trail was a path of brutal destruction, a swathe cut through the delicate, rotting web of Vance’s protections. Where Vance had woven tangled nets of twine, Grime had used a wrecking ball. Kaelen could see where a subtle ward of misdirection on the gate had been overloaded with raw power until it had simply burst, leaving behind a shimmering, ugly scorch mark visible only to a warlock’s sight. He followed the trail of magical wreckage up the path, the stench of Grime’s corrupt energy growing stronger, overriding the natural smell of the forest.

The trail of destruction led directly to the front door, or what was left of it. The heavy timber had been blasted inward, torn from its hinges and lay in splintered pieces in the entryway. The doorframe was blackened and corroded, pulsing with a faint, sickly purple light that told of crude, corrosive hexes. Grime had no time for lock-picking, magical or otherwise. Kaelen paused at the threshold, his gaze sweeping over the scene. Grime's magical signature wasn't dispersed; it was focused. A thick, ugly tendril of it led from the doorway, straight through the house, and downwards. A basement. Or a purpose-built vault. That was where Vance had kept his prize, the magnum opus he’d spent his life building. And that was where Grime was, or where he was going. The thought that Grime might still be inside, hunched over his prize in the darkness, sent a fresh wave of cold dread through Kaelen, the phantom sensation of a wicked beak and hateful eyes momentarily paralysing him.

He couldn't wait. Every second he hesitated was a second Grime had to secure whatever monstrous thing Vance had created. This house was a death trap, a labyrinth of magical tripwires and collapsing spells, and a powerful, vengeful warlock was somewhere in its depths. But there was no other way. He reached into his coat, his fingers bypassing the chalk and the sunbeam vial, closing instead around the small pouch of salt. He didn't use it to create a ward. He simply held it, the feel of the rough bag and the sharp, clean crystals within a grounding, tangible reality in a place where reality itself felt thin and frayed. He took one last, deep breath of the cool forest air, trying to hold onto its clean scent before plunging into the rot. Pushing aside the exhaustion, the fear, and the memory of the barn, he let the cold, hard resolve of the hunter take over. He stepped over the shattered remains of the door and into the waiting darkness of Elias Vance’s tomb.

The air inside was a physical presence, a dense, suffocating blanket of dust, mould, and magical static. Moonlight, filtered through the shattered doorway and grimy windows, illuminated a hoarder’s nightmare. Towers of books and newspapers leaned at precarious angles, threatening to collapse at the slightest vibration. Strange, unidentifiable objects—taxidermied animals with mismatched parts, brass contraptions bristling with wires, jars filled with murky liquids—covered every available surface, leaving only a narrow, canyon-like path through the clutter. But superimposed over the physical chaos was a far worse mess. The air shimmered with the residue of a thousand failed spells, a visual representation of the magical cacophony Kaelen felt pressing in on him. It was a psychic scream frozen in time, and cutting through it all was the foul, greasy river of Grime’s passage, a trail of pure corruption that smelled of open graves.

Kaelen moved with a slow, deliberate grace, his boots making almost no sound on the dusty floorboards. He was a ghost in a tomb, his senses extended far beyond his body, tasting the air, feeling the vibrations in the wood, reading the tangled grammar of the house's decay. Grime’s path was easy to follow, a trail of brute-force solutions. A delicate, shimmering web of a ward, intended to induce confusion, had been blasted apart, its remnants now clinging to the ceiling like charred candyfloss. A sigil of locking carved into a doorway had been simply overwhelmed with raw power, the wood around it splintered and blackened. Grime was a thug, and his magic had all the subtlety of a house brick thrown through a stained-glass window. It was this crudeness that gave Kaelen his only advantage. Grime left behind a mess, and in that mess was information. He was powerful, but he was loud, and he was single-minded.

The trail led him past a towering bookshelf and into what must have been a study. Here, the magical contamination was thicker, more complex. As he squeezed past a desk buried under piles of alchemical glassware, he felt a sudden, sickening lurch in his gut, a dizzying sense of temporal dislocation. To his left, a large, ornate mirror with a crack running down its centre hung on the wall. Its surface didn't reflect the room, but showed a flickering, ghostly image of a thin, haggard man with wild eyes—Elias Vance—pacing frantically, muttering to himself. The image stuttered, then was replaced by the hulking shadow of Grime, who didn't even look at the mirror as he passed, but the sheer force of his corrupting aura had been enough to shatter its delicate temporal enchantment. Now, the mirror was leaking time, spitting out fragments of its past. Kaelen felt a moment of Vance’s obsessive panic, a flash of Grime’s brutish rage, the echoes of their emotions trying to hook into his own mind. He shielded himself with a pulse of will, a mental wall of cold, grey calm, and hurried past, the feeling of other people's pasts scraping against his defences.

Grime’s trail of destruction ended abruptly at a heavy, iron-banded door at the far end of the study. This was it. The entrance to the vault. The door was set into a stone foundation that was clearly much older than the rest of the house, and it was sealed not with a mundane lock, but with a complex, multi-layered ward of immense strength. Even from a distance, Kaelen could feel the power humming within it, a deep, resonant thrum of containment. This was where Vance’s true skill had been focused. Grime had thrown himself against it with everything he had. The iron bands of the door were buckled and twisted, the stone around the frame was cracked and scorched, and the air fizzed with residual energy. But the door had held. It was battered, weakened, but still sealed. A wave of profound, cold relief washed over Kaelen, so potent it almost brought him to his knees. Grime wasn't waiting for him inside the vault. He was still trying to get in.

This changed everything. He wasn’t walking into an ambush; he was the ambush. But he couldn't face Grime here, surrounded by the house’s chaotic, dying magic. A stray discharge from their fight could bring the whole unstable structure crashing down, physically and magically. He needed a sterile field, a quiet space to work. He backed away from the vault door, retreating to the relative centre of the study. He slipped his satchel from his shoulder and pulled out a stick of chalk, the simple, reliable tool of his trade. He knelt on the dusty floorboards, ignoring the screaming of his exhausted body, and began to draw a circle around himself. This wasn't a simple circle of protection. It was something more complex, an inversion. He wasn't drawing a line to keep things out; he was drawing one to keep the chaos of the house from interfering with what was inside. It was a spell of absolute focus, a warlock’s soundproofed room. As he inscribed the final rune, he whispered a sibilant word of power. The world outside the chalk line didn't vanish, but it muted. The psychic scream of the house faded to a distant hum. The flickering, leaking time from the mirror became a silent film. He had carved out a small pocket of sanity in a house gone mad, a place where the only monster he had to face was the one hammering on the door. He rose to his feet inside his circle, took a deep, steadying breath, and turned to face the vault, ready.

### Chapter 5

He stood in the eye of his own private hurricane, the raging chaos of the house reduced to a silent, flickering panorama beyond the clean white line of his circle. The exhaustion was a physical weight, a leaden cloak on his shoulders, but the cold clarity of purpose was a sharper, stronger force. He could not outlast Grime in a battle of attrition. He was a depleted battery against a roaring, dirty generator. That meant he couldn't afford a long fight. It had to be quick, decisive, and brutal. He needed to bring the bear to his trap. Reaching out with a delicate thread of will, he didn’t touch the formidable ward on the vault door itself, but instead gently plucked at the frayed edges of the magic Grime had already damaged. He mimicked the resonant frequency of a key turning in a complex lock, a single, clear, silver chime that he pulsed out into the aether. It was the magical equivalent of announcing, *I’m in*. Then, he waited, pulling his own energy in, making himself as small and quiet as a spider in the corner of its web.

The response was not long in coming. It began with a distant, furious roar, a sound of pure frustration that seemed to make the very foundations of the house groan. It was followed by the crash of something heavy being overturned, then a series of percussive thuds as Grime began his journey back through the cluttered labyrinth. Heavy, running footsteps shook the floorboards, each one accompanied by the splintering of wood or the shattering of glass. The foul stench of Grime’s magic, the signature of rot and corruption, flooded the study, a toxic tide that broke against the invisible walls of Kaelen’s circle. The air outside the chalk line grew thick and dark, the moonlight from the window seeming to dim as if being physically consumed by the approaching malevolence.

The doorway to the study did not frame Grime’s entrance; it exploded. With a final, furious bellow, the hulking warlock burst through the wall beside the door in a shower of plaster, splintered lath, and ancient dust. Silas Grime in the flesh was even more repellent than his magical signature suggested. He was a mountain of a man, clad in stained work clothes that had long since surrendered to grease and filth. A greasy, dark ponytail was plastered to his thick neck, and his face was a fleshy mask of pure rage, his small, cunning eyes burning like hot coals in pockets of fat. He saw Kaelen, standing calmly in the circle, and his momentum halted. A slow, ugly grin spread across his face, a gash of yellowed teeth. “Well, look what the cat dragged in,” he growled, his voice like gravel churning in a cement mixer. “The Alistairs’ pet poodle. Come to fetch a stick for your masters?”

Kaelen ignored the jibe. His gaze was steady, his face a mask of weary calm that he hoped concealed the frantic drumming in his chest. The proximity of this much raw, hateful power was suffocating. “The rooster, Grime,” he said, his voice quiet but carrying in the suddenly still room. “At the Alistair house. It was a very specific choice. You went to a lot of trouble to tailor it. I want to know how you knew.”

Grime’s ugly grin widened. He took a lumbering step forward, stopping just short of the chalk line, his shadow falling across it like a stain. He laughed, a wet, choking sound that was full of phlegm and malice. “Knew?” he wheezed, wiping a hand across his mouth. “I didn’t know shit. Not the details. I just took a sniff. Every warlock’s got a thread you can pull, a little crack in their soul from when they were small and weak. I sent out a scry, looking for the fancy bitch’s new hire, and I found you. And I found your thread. Smelled like a barn, and dust, and a whole lot of screaming.” He leaned forward, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial, gloating rasp. “I just gave the smell a shape, poodle. Found a little screaming thing hiding in your past and gave it wings and a beak. It was fun to watch you flinch from a kays away. Now, get out of my circle. You’re standing on my property.”

The casual, brutish cruelty of it was more shocking than any calculated malevolence. It wasn't personal to Grime; it was just efficient. He had seen a wound and, without a second thought, had plunged his filthy fingers into it just to see what would happen. The cold resolve in Kaelen’s chest ignited into a white-hot, silent fury. The last vestiges of fear were burned away, leaving only a purpose as sharp and clean as a shard of glass. His magic, which had felt distant and depleted, surged in response to his rage, coiling in his gut, ready. “Vance’s work belongs to me now,” Grime snarled, his good humour evaporating as he remembered the prize. He raised a meaty hand, and a sphere of sickening purple-black energy, shot through with veins of pus-yellow light, coalesced above his palm. It crackled with the power of decay. “Last chance. Walk away.”

Kaelen didn’t answer. He simply raised his own hand. Grime bellowed and hurled the sphere of necrotic energy. It wasn’t a spell; it was a magical cannonball, raw and unsubtle. It flew across the room and slammed into the invisible barrier of Kaelen’s circle. The impact was immense. The chalk line sizzled and blackened, and a deafening shriek of shearing energies filled the air. The circle held, but the force of the blow threw Kaelen back a step, and the strain of maintaining the ward sent a lance of pain through his skull. He had his answer: he could not block these attacks for long. He had to change the game. As Grime gathered power for another blast, Kaelen flicked his wrist, not at Grime, but at the teetering tower of books and junk beside him. A precise, sharp nudge of telekinetic force, no bigger than a flicked pebble, struck the base of the pile. With a groan of protesting wood and paper, the entire ten-foot tower collapsed, an avalanche of rotting books, broken contraptions, and dusty artefacts crashing down directly in Grime’s path, burying him up to his waist.

The momentary distraction was all he needed. While Grime roared in fury, thrashing his way out of the debris, Kaelen reached out with his will, pulling on the chaotic magical energies that saturated the house. He didn’t try to wield them directly—that would be suicide—but he stirred them, agitated them, like poking a stick into a nest of sleeping wasps. The house, already unstable, responded with a scream of its own. The floorboards buckled. The cracked mirror on the wall finally shattered, and the temporal energy it had been leaking exploded outward in a silent, visible wave of distortion. The space outside Kaelen’s circle became a fractured nightmare. Ghostly images of Vance, of Grime’s earlier rampage, of decades of decay, flickered and overlapped. Time became a thick, stuttering slurry. Kaelen saw Grime simultaneously roaring in the present, blasting the vault door in the past, and lying broken on the floor in a possible future.

Grime, caught in the temporal blast, bellowed in confusion and rage. He was a creature of brute force, and this delicate, maddening chaos was anathema to him. He lashed out blindly, hurling bolts of corrosive magic in all directions. One blast went wide, striking the far wall and blasting a hole straight through to the night outside. Another struck the already weakened vault door. It didn't break the ward, but the impact, combined with the temporal flux, caused a sympathetic resonance to ripple through the very stones of the foundation. Kaelen felt it as a deep, shuddering chord. For a single, lucid second, the ghost of Elias Vance appeared, not as a flickering image, but as a solid, terrified presence, his hands raised, desperately trying to reinforce the very ward Grime was attacking. He was a memory, an echo trapped in the magic, replaying his most desperate moment.

In that instant, Kaelen saw his opening. He couldn't overpower Grime, and he couldn’t rely on the chaotic house to do his work for him. But he could use the creator’s magic against the intruder. Ignoring the hulking, raging warlock and the dizzying temporal storm, Kaelen focused his entire will on the spectral figure of Elias Vance. He wasn't trying to communicate with a ghost. He was targeting the magic the ghost represented, the original, powerful matrix of the vault's master ward. With a surge of desperate energy, he latched onto the pattern of Vance's spell, a complex, beautiful, and ferociously strong piece of magical architecture. He didn't try to control it. He just gave it a new target.
